metadata.name: Apply Decision Framework to Product Choice
metadata.description: Use principle-based decision framework to evaluate options systematically, document rationale, and make defensible product decisions
prerequisites: Decision framework template (or create one - see Task-Template-071)

dependencies: Optional: Task-Template-071 (Create Decision Framework) if you don't have one yet
outputs: Defensible choice that can withstand scrutiny

steps.description: Clearly state the decision to be made, why it matters, and what's at stake. Define decision type (feature prioritization, build vs. buy, hire, etc.). Set timeline for decision
steps.output: Clear decision statement with context and timeline

example.decision: Should we build RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generation) feature in-house or integrate existing API?
example.why_it_matters: Critical for Q2 product launch; impacts 6-month roadmap
example.timeline: Decision needed by end of week for engineering planning

steps.description: Enumerate all viable options (typically 2-5). Include status quo / do nothing as option if relevant. Briefly describe each option (1-2 sentences)
tips: Include hybrid options (e.g., 'build MVP in-house, then evaluate')
Don't prematurely eliminate options (evaluate systematically first)
Consult stakeholders to ensure no options missed

steps.description: Choose 3-7 criteria that matter for this decision. Use existing decision framework if you have one for this decision type, or define new criteria. Weight criteria by importance
example_criteria: User impact (30%): Estimated users affected × value delivered
Time to market (25%): Speed of delivery (important for Q2 launch)
Strategic value (15%): Builds core competency vs. commodity
Technical risk (10%): Probability of failure or delays

steps.description: Collect information needed to score each option against criteria. This may involve: talking to engineers, reviewing competitor analysis, checking budget, analyzing user research, etc.
steps.output: Sufficient data to score each option on each criterion
research_methods: Engineering estimates (for implementation cost, technical risk)

steps.description: For each option, assign score (1-10 scale) on each criterion. Document brief rationale for each score. Use consistent scale across all options
steps.output: Scorecard matrix with all options scored on all criteria
scoring_tips: Invert criteria where lower is better (e.g., 10 = low cost, 1 = high cost)
Provide brief justification for each score (1-2 sentences)
Be honest with uncertainty (note 'low confidence' scores)
Consider scoring in group to reduce individual bias

steps.description: Multiply each score by criterion weight, sum to get total weighted score per option. Rank options by total score

Review top-ranked option. Does it align with your gut feel? If not, investigate the discrepancy. Either: (1) intuition was wrong (framework reveals better choice), or (2) criteria/weights don't capture something important (adjust framework)
questions_to_ask: Would I be comfortable defending this choice to CEO/board?
Does this align with long-term product vision?
Am I overlooking qualitative factors not in criteria?
If scores were close, which option would I choose? Why?

steps.description: Select the top-ranked option (or make conscious choice to override if justified). Write decision memo documenting: decision, options considered, criteria used, scores, rationale, and next steps
steps.output: Decision memo ready for stakeholder distribution

sections: Executive summary (2-3 sentences: decision + key rationale)
Success metrics (how we'll know if this was right choice)

steps.description: Distribute decision memo to stakeholders (team, leadership, cross-functional partners). Invite feedback. Set deadline for input. Address concerns and refine if needed
steps.output: Stakeholders aligned on decision (or concerns surfaced for resolution)
communication_tips: Frame as 'proposed decision' if seeking input, 'final decision' if informing
Set response deadline (avoid indefinite feedback loops)

steps.description: Move forward with decision. Set calendar reminder for retrospective review (3-6 months). Track success metrics defined in memo. Document learnings to improve future framework
retrospective_questions: Was the decision correct? (measured by success metrics)
Did the criteria we used matter in practice?
What did we miss that we should add to framework?
Would we make the same choice with hindsight?
How can we improve the decision framework for next time?

quality_checklist: Decision clearly framed with context and timeline
Decision criteria explicit and weighted (3-7 criteria)
All options scored on all criteria with rationale
Top option aligns with intuition (or discrepancy investigated)
Success metrics defined for retrospective evaluation

example_scorecard.decision: Integrate OpenAI API (scored 7.6) - best for Q2 launch timeline despite lower strategic value

time_savings_analysis.without_framework: Debate in meetings (2-4 hours) + indecision/delays (days-weeks) + rework if wrong choice (weeks)
time_savings_analysis.with_framework: Structured evaluation (1-3 hours) + clear decision + stakeholder alignment
time_savings_analysis.time_saved: 1-3 hours on decision process + faster execution + reduced rework risk
quality_improvement: 80% reduction in decision reversal rate (better first-time decisions)

criteria_selection: Make criteria measurable where possible (not vague 'quality')
Include both short-term and long-term factors
Test criteria on past decisions (would they have led to good outcomes?)
scoring: Use consistent 1-10 scale across all criteria
Invert scales where needed (10 always = better)
Score independently before group discussion (reduce anchoring bias)
stakeholder_management: Share criteria before scoring (gather input on what matters)
Present scorecard in memo (transparency builds trust)
Acknowledge trade-offs explicitly (e.g., 'chose speed over long-term value')
Invite 'strong objections' with deadline (avoid endless debate)
Document dissent if consensus not reached (respectful disagreement)

common_pitfalls: Choosing criteria to justify pre-determined outcome (confirmation bias)
Too many criteria (analysis paralysis; obscures key trade-offs)
Criteria too vague ('user value' without definition)
No sanity check against intuition (miss important unmodeled factors)
Not documenting decision (lose rationale in 6 months)
when_to_use_framework: Recurring decision types (prioritization, vendor selection, hiring)
Decisions you'll need to defend (board, executives, team)
when_NOT_to_use: True emergencies (fire drill; no time for systematic analysis)
Highly exploratory (not enough information to score criteria)
